section.title: What this is about
section.para: This document serves as a mingle-mangle of thoughts about the game we're developing including goals, brainstorming, protocols of progress, architectural designs and anything that should be kept in mind. Feel free to add anything that in your opinion should be mentioned here. After consultation with other developers involved in the project, change parts of the documentation to fit to new ideas, but please DO NOT SIMPLY ERASE DOCUMENTATION THAT IS OUT OF DATE! Instead you should mark obsolete documentation by scratching out the text.

section.title: What we aim for
section.para: This project is about developing a multiplayer game appropiate to be played competitively as an eSport title. For us, a successful eSport title is characterized by:

listitem.para: Many players: A successful eSports game needs to have a lot of players. For example Counter-Strike had been the #1 (competitive) multiplayer game for years and thus was found on many LANs and tournaments although it did not serve a spectator-friendly environment. But because of that it was not able to bring eSports to such a high level of acceptance and interest as it is nowadays. This leads to the following point.

Many spectators: Spectators are very important for the success of a (e)sport. You may realize this by thinking of the success of 1on1 first-person-shooters like Painkiller or Quake. Especially Painkiller had a relativly small community of active players but achieved being shown on MTV since people like watching it. Nowadays, titles like League Of Legends and StarCraft2 combine both, many players and many spectators, and thus brought eSports to a new level.

A deep sportive characteristic: An eSports title must show up with a high level of sportive competition meaning that there should be least dependency on luck and various approches to win so no match looks like another. This is what World Of Warcraft was missed to become a big eSport title although there were an impressive amount of players and spectators.

section.title: Many players
section.para: To achieve a huge amount of players the game must fulfill the following properties:

listitem.para: Easy to learn: A game must be easy to learn so it does not scare off players that are new to the game.
Innovation: There should be a high degree of new elements that have not been seen in other games to make it more interesting.
Popular genre: Although there must be innovation the game should belong to a popular genre. For example, farming simulation is not appropriate here.
Low hardware requirements: To make it available for as many people as possible, there should be little hardware requirements so it can be played on almost any hardware.
Portability Because of the same argument as for low hardware requirements, the game should be available for any (common) platform.

section.title: Many spectators
section.para: To achieve a huge amount of spectators the game must fulfill the following properties:

listitem.para: Easy to learn/understand As for players, the spectator must be able to get into the game easily. Complicated rules scare them off.
Various possibilities of watching People must be able to tune in to matches anytime and anywhere so there must be different ways of gaining information about matches.

section.title: Deep sportive characteristic
section.para: To achieve a deep sportive characteristic the game must fulfill the following properties:

listitem.para: Little impact of luck: There should be little impact of luck since luck falsifies players' real skill and makes a match's result random.
High degree of competition: Players must be given the ressources and institutions to compete with each other.
Balance: There must be good game-balance. Otherwise strategies or certain approches will lead to a domination in the game making it boring to watch and play.
